Authors:
Wataru Aoki, Raymond Archambault, Jean Bérubé, Akiyoshi
Yamada
Title:
Tricholoma alpinum sp. nov., found under the five-needle
pines in the alpine and subalpine zones in Japan
Keywords:
AGARICALES, ECTOMYCORRHIZAL FUNGI, MULTI-GENES PHYLOGENY,
RELICT SPECIES, TRICHOLOMATACEAE
Abstract:
Alpine regions in Japan are characterized by the dwarf
pine, Pinus pumila, that is a circumboreal species distributed in the
eastern Eurasia. Although these regions are mostly conserved as National
Parks due to the specific nature and biome, quite limited fungal biota
is reported currently. We examined mushroom fungi under such environment
and found a unique yellowish-cap Tricholoma species. Multi-gene
molecular phylogenetic analysis and morphological observation for the
specimens showed that the Tricholoma species position to the sister
clade to T. fumosoluteum known in the North America under
alpinesubalpine zones. The Japanese yellowish-cap Tricholoma species
showed larger basidium size and pileipellis hyphal width as compared to
T. fumosoluteum, In addition, the Japanese yellowish-cap Tricholoma
species had cheilocystidia on the gill edge. Thus, we describe the
fungus as T. alpinum.
